text: Switzerland is known for its well-maintained roads, disciplined drivers and strict enforcement of traffic laws. If you’re planning to drive in Switzerland for the first time, it’s essential to familiarize yourself with the country’s traffic rules and signs. This article will help you understand what to expect and ensure a safe and smooth driving experience. General driving rules Switzerland has strict and well-enforced driving rules designed to ensure road safety. Whether you're planning a road trip through the mountains or navigating city streets, knowing the fundamental rules will help you avoid fines and drive confidently. Drive on the right: In Switzerland, vehicles drive on the right-hand side of the road and overtaking is done on the left. Seat belts are mandatory: All passengers, including those in the back seat, must wear seat belts at all times. Speed limits: 120 km/h on motorways (Autobahn) 100 km/h on expressways 80 km/h on rural roads 50 km/h in urban areas 30 km/h or lower in residential zones No right turn on red: Unlike in some other countries, you must wait for a green light to turn right at an intersection.
